title-group.subtitle: A Review of the Epidemiological Evidence

article-meta.aff: 2Duke University School of Medicine, Durham, North Carolina

author-notes.corresp: Paige E. Miller, PhD, MPH, RD, National Cancer Institute, 6130 Executive Blvd, EPN 4081, Rockville, MD 20852, USA; e-mail: paige.miller@nih.gov.

permissions.copyright-statement: © 2012 American Society for Parenteral and Enteral Nutrition
permissions.copyright-holder: The American Society for Parenteral and Enteral Nutrition

abstract.p: A number of epidemiological studies have investigated associations between various phytochemicals and cancer risk. Phytoestrogens and carotenoids are the two most commonly studied classes of phytochemicals; phytosterols, isothiocyanates, and chlorophyll also have been investigated, although to a much lesser extent. Because there have been no systematic reviews of the literature on all phytochemicals and cancer risk to date, this article systematically reviews 96 published epidemiological studies that examined associations between phytochemicals and cancer risk. Most studies found null associations between individual phytochemicals and cancer risk at various sites. In addition, results from past studies have been largely inconsistent, and observed associations have been of relatively modest magnitude. The most consistent protective effects were observed for higher levels—dietary intake, serum, plasma, or urinary metabolites—of β-carotene and renal cell cancer, β-cryptoxanthin and lung cancer, isothiocyanates and lung cancer, isothiocyanates and gastrointestinal cancer, lignans and postmenopausal breast cancer, and flavonoids and lung cancer. Although elevated risk of certain cancers with higher levels of certain phytochemicals was observed, an insufficient pool of studies examining the same associations or inconsistent findings across studies limit the ability to conclude that any one phytochemical increases cancer risk. Additional research is needed to support previously identified associations in cases where only one study has examined a particular relationship. Importantly, continued research efforts are needed to evaluate the cumulative and interactive effects of numerous phytochemicals and phytochemical-rich foods on cancer risk.

body.p: The National Cancer Institute (NCI) has recognized that prevention is a critical component in minimizing the number of individuals afflicted with cancer.1 Recent reports suggest that about one-third of the most common cancers in high-income countries can be prevented by eating a healthy, plant-based diet; being physically active; and maintaining a healthy weight.2 Despite the growing body of evidence linking diets rich in fruits, vegetables, legumes, whole grains, and nuts—foods rich in various phytochemicals—with cancer prevention, the underlying biological mechanisms explaining these beneficial effects remain unclear.

One group of compounds found in plant foods is phytochemicals, and it has been suggested that phytochemicals may play a role in cancer prevention. The term phytochemical includes essential nutrients, although it is more commonly used to describe nonessential plant chemicals, such as phytoestrogens and phytosterols. The 5 main categories of phytochemicals include carotenoids, phytosterols, isothiocyanates, chlorophyll, and phytoestrogens. It is possible that increased intakes of phytochemicals through diets rich in a variety of plant foods may help reduce cancer risk. However, plant-based foods are complex mixtures of bioactive compounds, thereby limiting efforts to examine the independent effect of any one single phytochemical. In addition to the challenges that arise from multicollinearity, thousands of phytochemicals have been identified, and there are likely more still to be discovered. In addition, there are many common food sources of phytochemicals, creating additional challenges in studying the singular effect of any one phytochemical.

Most of the cancer-preventive effects of phytochemicals have been shown in animal and cell culture studies3-16; human clinical trials examining the cancer-preventive potential of phytochemicals are lacking. However, a growing number of epidemiological studies have examined associations between phytochemicals—both dietary intake and serum or plasma levels—and cancer risk. Therefore, this systematic review examined the published epidemiological literature for prospective cohort studies that investigated associations between phytochemicals and cancer risk.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: A total of 96 publications are included in the present systematic review. PubMed and EMBASE were used to search for articles that examined phytochemicals and cancer risk. Studies that met the following inclusion criteria were retained: (1) prospective cohort study design; (2) human population; (3) outcome of primary cancer; (4) serum or plasma marker, urinary metabolite, or dietary intake captured; and (5) phytochemicals, whether dietary intake, plasma, serum, or urine, were quantified. Articles were excluded based on the following criteria: (1) case-control study design (subject to recall bias); (2) outcome of metastasis, secondary cancers, recurrence, or mortality; (3) outcome of nonmelanoma skin cancer; (4) only β-carotene or other vitamins or minerals examined; (5) only food examined, rather than specific phytochemicals; (6) animal and cell culture models; and (7) only intermediate markers, such as prostate-specific antigen (PSA), used as an outcome. Because β-carotene has been studied extensively, including in a meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials (RCTs),17 studies focusing on β-carotene alone were not included in the present review. However, if a study also examined other carotenoids, such as α-carotene and lutein, in addition to β-carotene, then we included this study. Originally, we included RCTs in our search criteria, but because there were no RCTs on phytochemicals other than β-carotene, no RCTs are included in the present review.

sec.title: Results and Discussion
sec.p: Table 1 shows the 5 main categories of phytochemicals (carotenoids, phytosterols, isothiocyanates, chlorophyll, and phytoestrogens), common food sources in the United States, and suggested mechanisms of action.

sec.title: Carotenoids
sec.p: Fifty of the 96 epidemiological studies examined associations between at least one of the carotenoids and cancer risk. Carotenoids are a class of phytochemicals comprising 2 subgroups: carotenes and xanthophylls. Several mechanisms of action have been suggested for the potential cancer-preventive role of carotenoids; the main mechanism that most often has been proposed is related to their antioxidant properties.18 Other mechanisms include their ability to modulate intercellular communication via gap junctions, alter intracellular signaling pathways, and enhance immune function.18 The most commonly studied carotenes include α-carotene, β-carotene, and lycopene, which are found in yellow, orange, red, and deep green fruits and vegetables (specific fruits and vegetables are listed in Table 1). The xanthophylls that have garnered the most attention in the literature include canthaxanthin, β-cryptoxanthin, lutein, and zeaxanathin. Overall, carotenoids appear to be best absorbed with small amounts of fat (3–5 g).19

Table 2 shows the results of studies examining associations between different phytochemicals and cancer risk. A number of cancer sites have been investigated for a potential relationship with carotenoids. Most studies reported null associations. The most consistent protective effects were observed for greater levels—dietary intake, serum, plasma, or urinary metabolites—of β-carotene and renal cell cancer as well as greater levels of β-cryptoxanthin and lung cancer. Three studies found that higher levels of β-carotene were inversely associated with renal cell cancer,20,21 although 1 study found a null association.22 Four studies reported an inverse association between β-cryptoxanthin and lung cancer,23-26 whereas 2 studies found null associations.27,28 For most other carotenoids and cancer sites, there were no studies that reported significant relationships, a greater number of studies that reported null associations, or only 1 study that examined a specific carotenoid and cancer site, in which case there was insufficient evidence to draw conclusions. Seven studies found that higher levels of certain carotenoids increased risk of cancer at a specific site; however, in most cases, at least 2 other studies reported null associations for the same carotenoid and cancer site. More research is needed to examine whether higher serum levels of β-carotene may increase risk of aggressive and stage III or IV prostate cancer, as shown in a nested case-control study within the Prostate, Lung, Colorectal, and Ovarian Cancer Screening Trial.29

tr.th: May Decrease Risk at Higher Levels
May Increase Risk at Higher Levels

fn.p: Reference numbers are in brackets. ER, estrogen receptor; PR, progesterone receptor.

fn.label: a
fn.p: Dietary intake estimate unless otherwise specified.

fn.label: g
fn.p: In subset with a single-nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) in the XRCC1 gene, potentially increasing DNA repair capacity.

fn.label: i
fn.p: Combined plasma and diet score to reflect long-term status.

fn.label: j
fn.p: Only among those with the manganese superoxide dismutase (MnSOD) Ala/Ala genotype.

fn.label: k
fn.p: In subset with low glutathione S-transferase (GST) activity (enzymes that metabolize isothiocyanates).

fn.label: m
fn.p: Only among those with GST deletion (conferring slower metabolism of isothiocyanates).

fn.label: n
fn.p: Never users of hormone replacement therapy only.

sec.p: Importantly, longer duration of individual β-carotene supplement use as well as lutein supplement use was found to increase lung cancer risk.30 No association was found between β-carotene supplement use and colon18 or ovarian31 cancers.

sec.title: Phytosterols
sec.p: Only one32 of the studies focused on phytosterols and cancer risk. Phytosterols are bioactive, plant-derived compounds similar in structure to cholesterol. Human cell culture and animal studies have shown that phytosterols can decrease cell proliferation4-7 and inhibit cancer cell growth.4,5 Despite the promising results in laboratory studies, the 1 epidemiological study examining phytosterols did not find a protective effect on cancer risk with greater intakes. It cannot be concluded that phytosterols are not associated with cancer risk from this 1 study. Only colorectal cancer has been investigated,32 but other cancer sites might be important. Furthermore, advances in dietary databases that include phytosterols may help facilitate future investigations.

sec.title: Isothiocyanates
sec.p: Five epidemiological studies examined associations between isothiocyanates, which are primarily found in cruciferous vegetables, and cancer risk. Cell culture studies have shown that isothiocyanates are capable of inhibiting phase I enzymes responsible for activating potential carcinogens, inducing phase II enzymes responsible for detoxifying potential carcinogens, and regulating cell proliferation and apoptosis.8-10 Animal studies have demonstrated that these compounds can inhibit the development of colonic aberrant crypt foci, which are precursors of colon adenoma and cancer,33 and reduce the incidence and multiplicity of chemically induced tumors.13

One study examined colorectal cancer,34 a second study investigated colon and rectal cancer separately,35 2 studies examined lung cancer,36,37 and another study investigated stomach cancer.38 With the exception of the 1 study that examined rectal cancer, all studies reported a protective effect of higher levels of isothiocyanates. Results are most promising for lung cancer, as 2 independent studies reported inverse associations. One of these studies,37 which examined urinary metabolites of isothiocyanates, reported that the protective effect of isothiocyanates was only among those with a GST deletion, conferring slower metabolism of isothiocyanates. Additional studies are needed to strengthen the scientific evidence for isothiocyanates and a reduced risk of colorectal, colon, and stomach cancers. Further examinations of potentially important diet-gene interactions involved in the relationship between isothiocyanates and cancer risk would be valuable.

sec.title: Chlorophyll
sec.p: Associations between chlorophyll, the ubiquitous pigment in green vegetables, and cancer risk were examined in 1 epidemiological study.14 Animal studies suggest that chlorophyll may act as a blocking agent against chemical initiation of carcinogenesis,15 and in particular, it may block the reactivity of heme—a pro-oxidant found in highest concentrations in red meat but also in poultry and fish—in the gastrointestinal tract, thereby preventing the formation of potentially carcinogenic heme metabolites.15 It is thought that chlorophyll is most effective when consumed simultaneously with heme.15 Although animal and cell culture studies have identified biologically plausible mechanisms linking chlorophyll with a reduced risk of cancer, the 1 epidemiological study that examined the relationship between chlorophyll and cancer (specifically, colorectal cancer) did not find a significant relationship.

sec.title: Phytoestrogens
sec.p: Thirty-nine studies examined associations between at least 1 phytoestrogen and cancer risk. Phytoestrogens are bioactive compounds that are similar in structure to endogenous estrogens. The 3 main subgroups of phytoestrogens are lignans, flavonoids, and coumestans. Although phytoestrogens are most widely recognized for their weak estrogenic activity, they have a variety of other biologic activities that may influence cancer risk. Animal and cell culture studies have shown phytoestrogens to have antioxidant, antiproliferative, and antiangiogenic activities independent of estrogenic properties and also to inhibit the effects of cytokines, growth factors, and several enzymes, such as the enzymes responsible for steroid hormone metabolism.11,12,16,39,40 It is important to note that phytoestrogens are in a wide variety of foods aside from soybeans and soy products; examples include a number of fruits and vegetables, other beans, flaxseed and other seeds, whole grains, nuts, chocolate, spices, tea, and red wine.

Some, but not all, studies found that greater levels of total flavonoids or specific types of flavonoids were inversely associated with lung,41-44 premenopausal breast,45,46 postmenopausal breast,47,48 all breast,49,50 stomach,51 prostate,52,53 pancreatic,54 ovarian,55 and/or colorectal cancers,56 with the most consistent associations shown for flavonoids and lung cancer. Lignans were not consistently associated with breast cancer classified as one cancer type,57-60 but in the 1 study that examined postmenopausal breast cancer risk,61 researchers reported that higher intakes may be protective, but only among those who had never used hormone replacement therapy. However, more studies are needed to confirm this association. It is possible that greater intakes of coumestrol, a type of coumestan, may protect against estrogen receptor negative and progesterone receptor negative (ER−/PR−) breast cancer, but similarly, additional studies are warranted to support findings from the 1 study that investigated this relationship.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Studying any one phytochemical in isolation is limited because phytochemicals may act synergistically—not only with other phytochemicals but also with other components in food—to reduce cancer risk. Phytochemicals are highly correlated with other plant components, such as dietary fiber and numerous vitamins and minerals, challenging efforts to determine which specific factor is accounting for observed associations with cancer risk. Although most associations were null, a few promising findings were uncovered in this review. The most consistent protective effects were observed for higher levels—dietary intake, serum, plasma, or urinary metabolites—of β-carotene and renal cell cancer, β-cryptoxanthin and lung cancer, isothiocyanates and lung cancer, isothiocyanates and gastrointestinal cancer, lignans and postmenopausal breast cancer, and flavonoids and lung cancer. These observed relationships require additional investigation, ideally in RCTs.

It is important to consider that 10 independent studies18,29,51,62-68 reported an increased cancer risk with higher dietary intakes or serum, plasma, or urine metabolite levels of certain phytochemicals. In some cases, there was an insufficient pool of studies examining the same associations, and we cannot conclude that any one phytochemical is likely to increase cancer risk. In other cases, there were inconsistent findings across studies, which also limit our ability to conclude that any one phytochemical increases cancer risk. Additional research is needed to support previously identified associations in cases where only 1 study has examined a particular relationship. It is of particular concern that longer duration of individual β-carotene and individual lutein supplements was found to increase lung cancer risk.30 These epidemiological findings support evidence from 2 RCTs, in which high-dose β-carotene supplements increased lung cancer risk in smokers and asbestos workers.69,70

In light of the numerous plausible biological mechanisms linking phytochemicals with cancer prevention, continued research efforts are needed to evaluate further their potential cancer-preventive properties as part of a largely plant-based diet. Importantly, these efforts should aim to evaluate the cumulative and interactive effects of various phytochemicals and phytochemical-rich foods on cancer risk.

sec.title: Clinical Implications
sec.p: Based on findings from this review, which showed mostly null associations between individual phytochemicals and cancer, there is insufficient evidence to recommend to patients any one single phytochemical to reduce risk of cancer. Furthermore, there is no evidence to support individual supplementation of phytochemicals for cancer prevention; on the contrary, supplementation of β-carotene and lutein may increase lung cancer risk. Although it appears that no single phytochemical can account for the protective effect observed from a largely plant-based diet rich in fruit, vegetables, beans, nuts, seeds, and vegetable oils, methodological limitations, including an inability to examine potentially synergistic effects of phytochemicals, may have limited our ability to fully capture possible benefits of these compounds. Studies that examine phytochemical-rich foods and combinations of these foods will likely provide useful insight and evidence that can be used by registered dietitians and other healthcare professionals when discussing diet and cancer prevention with patients.
